coredata.dc:description:
Summary
Despite much work studying ex vivo multipotent stromal cells (MSCs), the identity and characteristics of MSCs in vivo are not well defined. Here, we generated a CD73-EGFP reporter mouse to address these questions and found EGFP+ MSCs in various organs. In vivo, EGFP+ mesenchymal cells were observed in fetal and adult bones at proliferative ossification sites, while in solid organs EGFP+ cells exhibited a perivascular distribution pattern. EGFP+ cells from the bone compartment could be clonally expanded ex vivo from single cells and displayed trilineage differentiation potential. Moreover, in the central bone marrow CD73-EGFP+ specifically labeled sinusoidal endothelial cells, thought to be a critical component of the hematopoietic stem cell niche. Purification and molecular characterization of this CD73-EGFP+ population revealed an endothelial subtype that also displays a mesenchymal signature, highlighting endothelial cell heterogeneity in the marrow. Thus, the CD73-EGFP mouse is a powerful tool for studying MSCs and sinusoidal endothelium.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Perivascular Localization of MSCs in Various Organs

(A, C, and E) EGFP+ MSCs were found in vicinity to vessels in various tissues such as (A) uterus, (C) liver, and (E) white fat. The perivascular distribution pattern was demonstrated by immunostainings against PECAM (for detailed alignment see confocal z stack analysis in E, right panel).

(B, D, and F) FACS analysis demonstrated expression of typical MSC markers (CD146, Sca-1) in the CD45–/EGFP+ fraction of primary cells isolated from these organs (filled curve, open curve represents isotype control).

(G) Cultured EGFP+ cells from fat tissue displayed typical MSC markers in flow cytometric analysis and (H) could be differentiated into osteocytes (alizarin red), adipocytes (oil red O), and chondrocytes (trypan blue).
All FACS images show representative plots from at least three mice. Scale bars in (A), (C), and (H), 100 μm, and (E), 25 μm.
Bone Compartment Contains CD73-EGFP+ MSCs

(A and B) Sections of embryonic (E16.5) rib (A) and adult femur epiphysis (B) revealed distinct EGFP+ cell formations at the proliferative sites of peri- and endochondral ossification, respectively (left panels are composite pictures).
(C) Spindle-shaped EGFP+ cells migrated from cultured epiphysis (upper left corner, white line) onto the culture dish (insets show bright-field pictures).
(D) Rare EGFP+/EMCN–/PDGFRα+ cells were observed at the inner endosteal surface of cortical bones.
(E) Bone fragments were covered with elongated EGFP+ cells after 3–5 days in culture.
(F) Flow cytometry analysis of total bone marrow (BM) revealed a small percentage of CD45–/EGFP+ cells (representative plot from 14 individual mice).
(G) Most CD45+/EGFP+ BM cells were lymphoid blood cells of the B cell (B220) and T cell (CD3, CD4) lineage (data are represented as mean ± SD, n = 4 mice).
(H) Sca-1 was highly expressed in the CD45–/EGFP+ BM fraction (filled curve, open curve represents isotype control; representative plot from 4 mice).
(I) Typical colony-forming units-fibroblasts (CFU-Fs) in BM bulk cultures consist of a mixture of EGFP+ and EGFP– cells and contained some CD45+ blood cells.
(J) Pure EGFP+ colonies of primary BM cultures differentiated into the adipogenic and osteogenic lineages (note loss of EGFP during differentiation).
Scale bars in (A)–(C), (I), and (J), 100 μm; (D) and (E), 200 μm. See also Figure S3.
CD73-EGFP Labels True Multipotent MSCs
(A) After four passages, EGFP+ and EGFP– cell fractions were sorted by flow cytometry (purity analysis in middle and right panel).
(B) Cultured EGFP+ and EGFP– BM cells exhibited typical MSC markers by flow cytometry.
(C) Trilineage differentiation of EGFP+ BM cells into osteocytes (alizarin red), adipocytes (oil red O), and chondrocytes (trypan blue).
(D) FACS-sorted EGFP+ cells from bone fragments gave rise to fibroblastic colonies.
(E) Single-cell-derived colony showing EGFP fluorescence in culture.
(F) Trilineage differentiation potential of an expanded CD45–/PECAM–/EGFP+ single-cell clone into osteocytes (alizarin red), adipocytes (oil red O), and chondrocytes (trypan blue).

All FACS images show representative plots from 8 individual experiments. Scale bars in (C) and (E), 100 μm; (D), 200 μm; and (F), 200 μm (osteocytes), 100 μm (adipocytes), and 50 μm (chondrocytes). See also Figure S3.
CD73-EGFP Labels a Specific Subset of Endothelial Cells in the BM
(A) Femur sections showed elongated EGFP+ structures in the BM.
(B) Immunostaining against CD45 demonstrated non-hematopoietic identity of these structures (arrow: EGFP+/CD45+ blood cell).
(C) 3D reconstruction by confocal z stack analysis revealed a network of EGFP+ sinusoidal cells throughout the BM (see also Movie S1 of two-photon imaging).

(D) EGFP+ sinusoidal structures expressed the endothelial marker PECAM (upper panel). The mesenchymal marker PDGFRα was strongly expressed in perivascular cells adjacent to the EGFP+ endothelial layer (arrowheads depict nuclei of positive perivascular cells).
(E) Confocal z stack analysis (13 μm total, shown in different layers) showing membrane-bound PECAM expression surrounding EGFP+ cells.
Scale bars in (A)–(D), 25 μm; (E), 10 μm. See also Figures S4 and S5.
CD73-EGFP Specifically Labels BM Sinusoidal Endothelial Cells
(A) Colonies of primary BM bulk cultures could yield endothelial networks during culture as shown by immunostainings against PECAM and endomucin (EMCN).
(B) Sorted EGFP+/PECAM+ cells from those BM cultures were re-plated on Matrigel and gave again rise to network formation.

(C) Three populations of CD45– cells were FACS sorted from BM based on CD73-EGFP and PECAM expression (each from 3 mice). Gates were placed based on fluorescence minus ones (FMOs) and drawn tightly to prevent contamination of sorted populations (one representative plot is shown).

(D) Single-cell multiplex gene expression analysis showing expression of genes encoding mesenchymal and endothelial markers in single CD45–/EGFP+/PECAM– (n = 8 cells from 3 mice), CD45–/EGFP–/PECAM+ (n = 38 cells from 3 mice), and CD45–/EGFP+/PECAM+ cells (n = 44 cells from 3 mice); results were calculated by the change-in-cycling-threshold (ΔCt) method and are presented relative to those of B2m (black, beyond detection level).
(E) In young mice (5 weeks), only sinusoidal cells in the diaphysis are EGFP+, whereas metaphysis “type H endothelium” is EGFP–.
(F) CD73-EGFP exclusively labels sinusoidal endothelial cells (arrowheads), but not arterioles (arrows) in the lumen or the cortical bone as shown by immunostainings against PECAM.
(G) Immunostainings against Sca-1 revealed EGFP–/Sca-1high arteriolar cells in the lumen and cortical bone, while sinusoidal cells are clearly EGFP+/Sca-1low.
(H) Confocal z stack analysis of whole-mount sternum confirmed respective EGFP and Sca-1 expression in endothelial subtypes.

(I) c-kit+ hematopoietic cells located adjacent or in close vicinity to EGFP+ sinusoidal structures as shown by immunostainings. Distribution and mean distance of c-kit+ cells (n = 5 mice) versus all mononuclear cells (MNC, n = 6 mice) are shown in the charts (p < 0.001).
Data are represented as mean ± SD. Scale bars in (A) and (B), 100 μm; (E), (F), and (I), 50 μm; (G), 25 μm; and (H), 200 μm. See also Figures S4 and S5.
RNA-Seq Analysis Revealed Differentially Expressed Genes in Endothelial Subpopulations

(A) Three populations of CD45– cells were FACS sorted from BM based on CD73-EGFP and PECAM expression (see Figure 5C), and gene expression of the sorted cells was examined by RNA-seq analysis (n = 3 mice). Hierarchical clustering in a phylogenetic tree plot revealed closely clustered populations.

(B) PECAM and CD73 expression correlate to respective sorting parameters of the three different populations. Significance of difference was determined by an unpaired two-sided and pairwise t test with Bonferroni correction for multiple testing.

(C and D) Expression of selected (C) endothelial genes Emcn, Cdh5 (endomucin, VE-cadherin), and (D) mesenchymal genes Pdgfra, Lepr (PDGF receptor alpha, leptin receptor) by the three different sorted populations (for further genes, see Figure S6).

(E) E-selectin (Sele) and Vcam1 (Vcam1) were stronger expressed in EGFP+ sinusoidal cells compared to EGFP– arteriolar endothelium. Significance of difference was determined by an unpaired two-sided and pairwise t test with Bonferroni correction for multiple testing.

(F and G) E-selectin (F) and Vcam1 (G) expression were confirmed by immunostainings on EGFP+ sinusoidal cells (arrows), but not on arterioles (arrowheads, see also Figures 5F and 5G) in the lumen or the cortical bone; the slight background is due to Vcam1 expression on blood cells.
Data are represented as mean ± SD. Scale bars, 50 μm.
Molecular Characterization of CD73-EGFP+ BM Sinusoidal Cells

Heatmap visualizing the expression of previously published gene signatures (core enrichment genes) of stromal stem cells and endothelial-like cells in the indicated FACS-sorted cell subpopulations (sECs, sinusoidal endothelial cells; aECs, arteriolar endothelial cells; MSCs, multipotent stromal cells). Z-score-transformed gene expression data from three biological replicates (left panel) are shown. Assessment of gene signature activity in the three FACS-sorted cell populations is shown. Significance of difference was determined by an unpaired two-sided and pairwise t test with Bonferroni correction for multiple testing (right panels). Data are represented as mean ± SD. See also Figure S6.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Despite much work studying ex vivo multipotent stromal cells (MSCs), the identity and characteristics of MSCs in vivo are not well defined. Here, we generated a CD73-EGFP reporter mouse to address these questions and found EGFP+ MSCs in various organs. In vivo, EGFP+ mesenchymal cells were observed in fetal and adult bones at proliferative ossification sites, while in solid organs EGFP+ cells exhibited a perivascular distribution pattern. EGFP+ cells from the bone compartment could be clonally expanded ex vivo from single cells and displayed trilineage differentiation potential. Moreover, in the central bone marrow CD73-EGFP+ specifically labeled sinusoidal endothelial cells, thought to be a critical component of the hematopoietic stem cell niche. Purification and molecular characterization of this CD73-EGFP+ population revealed an endothelial subtype that also displays a mesenchymal signature, highlighting endothelial cell heterogeneity in the marrow. Thus, the CD73-EGFP mouse is a powerful tool for studying MSCs and sinusoidal endothelium.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Breitbach et al. generated a CD73-EGFP reporter mouse that enabled identification and tracking of multipotent stromal cells in vivo. CD73-EGFP also labeled sinusoidal endothelial cells within the bone marrow, enabling the molecular characterization of this important endothelial component of the hematopoietic stem cell niche.

ce:section.ce:para: Multipotent stromal cells (MSCs) were initially described several decades ago by Friedenstein et al. as colony-forming fibroblastic cells isolated from bone marrow (Friedenstein et al., 1970). Still today MSCs are selected by classic adherence and in vitro culture methods due to the absence of specific markers for prospective isolation. MSCs are defined in cell culture by a set of surface markers and their differentiation capacity to various mesenchymal cell types, such as osteocytes, adipocytes, and chondrocytes (Dominici et al., 2006). In order to specify these MSCs as true mesenchymal stem cells, their multipotency and sustained self-renewal capacity needs to be assessed in vivo. Numerous studies have investigated the use of ex vivo expanded MSCs in experimental animal disease models and reported enhanced tissue repair, but it is still unclear whether these effects mimic the natural function of their in vivo counterparts, in particular because their molecular characteristics and function might be altered by the ex vivo purification approach (Bara et al., 2014). Thus, despite the abundance of experimental data the current understanding of multipotent stromal cells and mesenchymal stem cells in vivo remains elusive in regard to their developmental origin, organ distribution, endogenous plasticity, potential heterogeneity, and also physiological roles. Therefore, new approaches such as animal models for the identification of MSCs and closely related cell types in vivo are warranted.

We have therefore searched for MSC markers in the literature and identified CD73 as a promising molecule. We have generated a reporter mouse, in which EGFP is expressed under control of a CD73 bacterial artificial chromosome (BAC) promoter including distal regulatory elements (CD73-EGFP). Herein, we show that CD73-EGFP labels perivascular cells in different organs and greatly facilitates enrichment of MSC-like cells from the fat and bone compartment with typical marker expression and tri-lineage differentiation potential in vitro. Moreover, in the bone marrow (BM) the CD73-EGFP reporter specifically labels also sinusoidal endothelial cells. These represent a distinct endothelial subpopulation, implicated to be an important part of the hematopoietic stem cell niche (Winkler et al., 2012). The in vivo labeling of this specific niche component and of the MSCs allowed their direct visualization, purification, and molecular as well as functional characterization.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Establishment and Functionality of the CD73-EGFP Reporter
ce:section.ce:para: Our literature search identified CD73 as a strong candidate marker molecule for the direct identification of multipotent stromal cells (MSCs) (see STAR Methods for further details). We therefore assessed the suitability of the CD73 gene as a MSC specific marker in more detail by performing qPCR analyses on four MSC lines, that had been established and extensively characterized earlier in our lab (Breitbach et al., 2007), as well as other cell types. As shown in Figure S1A, CD73 gene expression levels varied between the different MSC lines (0.31- to 2.78-fold compared to mean MSC expression levels, n = 3) but were clearly higher than in non-MSCs (0- to 0.18-fold).

Based on these findings, we designed a BAC expression vector, in which EGFP is driven by the endogenous CD73 promoter including regulatory elements (Figure S1B). Transfection of our established MSC lines with the CD73-EGFP vector yielded EGFP+ cells with typical MSC morphology (Figure S1C); these cells could be differentiated in vitro into the osteogenic and adipogenic lineage (Figure S1D). Moreover, immunocytochemistry revealed a loss of EGFP fluorescence during the differentiation to osteoblasts, as shown by osteocalcin expression in EGFP-dim cells (Figure S1E). These findings demonstrated selective transgene expression only in undifferentiated multipotent cells, indicating that CD73 is a suitable marker to label these cells.

Next, we generated transgenic CD73-EGFP BAC mice and first analyzed EGFP expression in kidney and lung, which are known to contain high mRNA levels of CD73 in epithelium (Resta et al., 1993; Zimmermann, 1992). Tissue sections showed strong EGFP signals in kidney tubules and lung epithelial cells and immunohistochemical stainings clearly confirmed specificity of the transgene expression, as only kidney and lung cells displaying CD73 antibody staining were EGFP+ (Figure S2). The transgenic mice had normal litter sizes and did not display an overt phenotype; qPCR revealed a single insertion of the BAC construct (data not shown).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Perivascular Localization of MSCs in Various Organs
ce:section.ce:para: Next, we investigated whether our transgenic mouse model enabled the detection of MSCs in situ. To this aim, we examined CD73-EGFP expression in tissue sections of uterus, liver, and white fat, which were described to comprise appreciable numbers of MSCs (da Silva Meirelles et al., 2006; Gargett et al., 2009; Gimble et al., 2007). EGFP+ cells could be detected in situ in vicinity to or directly lining PECAM+ vessel structures in all of these organs (Figures 1A, 1C, and 1E). In accordance with the initial qPCR analysis (see Figure S1A), the vast majority of endothelial cells were EGFP–, and just a small population of lymphatic vessels in the uterus showed expression of the transgene (Figure S3A). To further characterize the nature of the EGFP+ cells, tissues were dissociated and primary cells were analyzed by flow cytometry. The majority of EGFP+ cells expressed the mesenchymal markers CD146 and Sca-1 (Figures 1B, 1D, and 1F). Furthermore, EGFP+ cells from white fat, the tissue type that besides BM is most frequently used for MSC isolation, were expanded in vitro and showed typical fibroblastic morphology even after several passages. Flow cytometry analysis of these cultured white-fat-derived cells revealed lack of the hematopoietic markers CD45 and CD11b and expression of the typical MSC markers CD44 and Sca-1 (Figure 1G). Importantly, the cells could be differentiated into the osteogenic, adipogenic, and chondrogenic lineages (Figure 1H), suggesting that the EGFP+ cells of white fat tissue are MSCs.

ce:section.ce:section-title: CD73-EGFP Labels Chondrogenic Progenitor Cells and MSCs in the Bone Compartment
ce:section.ce:para: From transplantation studies, MSCs are widely recognized to produce chondrocytes and osteoblasts during bone development and bone regeneration, but direct visualization is hampered by the lack of suitable in vivo models. To confirm the existence of MSCs in this mesenchymal compartment, we first analyzed EGFP expression in developing bones of the embryo and in the growth plate of adult long bones. In ribs of E16.5 embryos, EGFP fluorescence was seen in the outer cell layer labeling the perichondrium, which is thought to contain the mesenchymal precursor cells (Figure 2 A). A similar pattern could be observed in sections of the epiphysis of adult femur, where EGFP was found to label chondrogenic progenitors and early chondrocytes in the zone of proliferation (Figure 2B). The gradient of EGFP fluorescence intensity demonstrated the loss of CD73 expression during the maturation of chondrocytes by perichondral and endochondral ossification, as seen before in our cell-culture osteogenic differentiation experiments (see above, Figure S1E). To further prove that the EGFP+ cells are MSCs with an endogenous osteochondral differentiation potential, we cultured dissected adult femur epiphyses according to a recently published protocol (Cheng et al., 2012). In time-lapse microscopy experiments, we could demonstrate outgrowth of EGFP+ cells from the truncated epiphysis (Figure 2C) onto the culture dish. These EGFP+ cells displayed MSC morphology and could be propagated in culture for several passages (Figure S3B). Their marker expression (Figure S3C) and differentiation potential (Figure S3D) suggested that EGFP+ cells from the epiphysis are multipotent cells. Within the bone compartment, MSCs are also supposed to reside at the inner endosteal surface of cortical bones. We therefore screened next diaphysis sections by microscopic analysis and could find rare EGFP+ cells lining the bone; these expressed PDGFRα and lacked the endothelial marker endomucin (Figure 2D). To test the proliferative capacity of these cells, we crushed bone diaphysis and kept the bone fragments under MSC culture conditions. After 3–5 days, elongated EGFP+ cells covered large areas of the inner side of the bones (Figure 2E) suggesting expansion of the few existing MSCs lining the bone.

In order to assess the overall distribution of EGFP+ MSCs in the bone compartment, we performed flow cytometry analysis on freshly isolated CD73-EGFP mouse BM cells of which 1.45% ± 0.5% were EGFP+ (n = 14, Figure 2F). Most of these EGFP+ cells were CD45+ (92.8% ± 5.8%, n = 6). Blood lineage marker analysis revealed an enrichment for lymphoid cell types in the EGFP+ population, B220+ B cells (56.3% ± 9.0% versus 19.2% ± 6.5% in total BM, n = 4) and CD3+ T cells (26.0% ± 5.0% versus 9.1% ± 1.3%, n = 4; Figure 2G), the latter primarily of the CD4+ lineage (17.0% ± 4.2% versus 4.4% ± 1.1%, n = 4). As MSCs are negative for the blood cell marker CD45, we further characterized the rare EGFP+/CD45– cell fraction (about 0.1% of total BM cells) to prove that our marker labels MSCs. In additional flow cytometry measurements Sca-1 expression, previously shown to enrich for MSCs (Morikawa et al., 2009), was detected on the majority of these cells (69.6% ± 6.6%, n = 4; Figure 2H), suggesting a MSC-like character. We analyzed this more in detail by plating whole BM cells and screening the cultures after 2 weeks for EGFP expression in developing colonies. We found that 0.010% ± 0.002% (n = 5) of whole BM cells gave rise to colonies and that all of the colony-forming units-fibroblasts (CFU-Fs) contained EGFP+ cells. Interestingly, only 30.7% ± 10.5% of the cells within one colony were EGFP+, suggesting that CFU-Fs represent a heterogeneous population of cells (Figure 2I). In order to analyze the in vitro differentiation potential, we marked colonies that almost exclusively consisted of EGFP+ cells and initiated differentiation into the osteogenic or the adipogenic lineage. After 25 days, formation of bone matrix or adipocytes could be observed in these colonies, respectively, proving at the clonal level the multilineage potential of the BM-derived EGFP+ cell fraction (Figure 2J). Importantly, as seen before in the transfected MSC lines (see Figure S1E), EGFP expression was lost during the differentiation process and remained only visible in cells still displaying typical MSC-like morphology (spindle shaped cells in Figure 2J). Due to the observation that the percentage of EGFP+ cells decreased over time, when expanding BM bulk cultures over several passages, we wondered whether the observed variation of EGFP expression within the cultured BM cells could be an indicator for their plasticity, as it could be lost during prolonged culturing (Bara et al., 2014). This prompted us to sort EGFP+ and EGFP– MSC-like cells from bulk cultures after four passages using flow cytometry (Figure 3 A), culture these cells for another passage, and examine thereafter their MSC features. Flow cytometry analysis revealed similar marker expression in both populations (Figure 3B), and the EGFP+ cells could be differentiated into the osteogenic, adipogenic, and chondrogenic lineage suggesting that they include multipotent cells (Figure 3C). By contrast, sorted EGFP– cells displayed only a very limited differentiation potential, as either none or only a very small number of cells gave rise to the respective derivatives (data not shown). This suggests that CD73 expression is an important indicator for the multipotency of MSCs from the bone compartment.

Instead of bulk cultures, we next directly isolated MSCs from the bone compartment based on CD73-EGFP expression. For this purpose, we took advantage of another method utilizing enzymatic digestion of bone fragments, that is known to yield high numbers of MSCs with extensive proliferative capacity in vitro (Short et al., 2009). We analyzed the cells by flow cytometry and could verify low numbers (0.83% ± 0.56% of total cells, n = 3) of EGFP+ cells within this population, of which a subset was found to be CD45+ blood cells (28.4% ± 11.0% of EGFP+ cells). Culture of different fractions of fluorescence-activated cell sorting (FACS)-sorted EGFP+ cells gave rise to typical CFU-Fs only in the CD45–, but not in the CD45+ nor in the EGFP– cell population. The number of CFU-F per seeded cells was assessed after 14 days of culture (Figure 3D) and revealed a strong enrichment of proliferating cells (1 colony per 12.7 ± 3.4 EGFP+ cells), when using CD73-EGFP as a marker for the prospective isolation of MSCs. Most of the colonies kept their EGFP fluorescence during culture (77% ± 4%) and the cells could be expanded over several passages (Figure S3E). The cells expressed typical MSC markers in vitro and were devoid of hematopoietic markers as demonstrated by flow cytometry (Figure S3F). Their multipotent differentiation potential substantiated their MSC character (Figure S3G).

To further prove that EGFP+ cells from the bone compartment are multipotent stromal cells, we directly sorted primary single CD45–/PECAM–/EGFP+ cells from transgenic mice into individual wells by FACS and found that these cells could be successfully cultured in vitro giving rise to clonal EGFP+ colonies at a high frequency (34.1% ± 4.3%, n = 5, 158 out of 480 single sorted cells; Figure 3E). More than half of these colonies could be further expanded by passaging (91 of 158, 57.6%), supporting their self-renewal potential. Next, following extensive expansion (to more than 1 million cells corresponding to 20 population doublings) 12 single-cell clones were tested for their combined differentiation potential into the osteogenic, adipogenic, and chondrogenic lineages. All of these clones displayed mesenchymal differentiation capacity and seven (58.3%) showed even a trilineage differentiation potential (Figure 3F), demonstrating that CD73-EGFP enables the identification and prospective isolation of a cell population containing multipotent stromal cells from the intact bone compartment.

ce:section.ce:section-title: CD73-EGFP Labels a Specific Subset of Endothelial Cells in the BM
ce:section.ce:para: We next sought to explore the specific localization of EGFP+ cells within the bone in order to characterize their distribution pattern in more detail. Interestingly, sections of long bones displayed distinct patterns of elongated EGFP+ cells lining continuously the sinusoids in the central areas of the BM (Figure 4 A). Stainings against the pan-hematopoietic marker CD45 and various blood cell lineages revealed that these elongated EGFP+ cells were definitively of non-hematopoietic nature (Figures 4B, S4A, and S4B). In contrast to our flow cytometric analysis (see Figure 2F), we could only detect a minor amount of small and roundish EGFP+/CD45+ blood cells with immunostainings, accounting for only 12% of the EGFP+ population (assessed by counting of nucleated cells in stained sections). Rather, the vast majority of EGFP+ cells in the sections were elongated and CD45–. Also the total number of EGFP+ cells was much higher than expected from our flow cytometry analysis, suggesting that the EGFP+/CD45– cell fraction is fragile and appears to be preferentially lost during the isolation procedure. In order to characterize the cellular nature of these CD73-EGFP+ structures in the BM, we performed confocal and two-photon microscopy analysis. Both techniques revealed a continuous three-dimensional EGFP+ network, forming cavities within the densely packed BM (Figure 4C; Movie S1). That prompted us to investigate whether these EGFP+ cells could be the endothelial layer of the BM sinusoids. We therefore performed immunohistochemical stainings on femur sections and found that the EGFP+ network consisted of an endothelial cell population expressing PECAM and endomucin (Figures 4D, upper panel, S4C). Next, we used high-resolution confocal z stack analysis on thick (30–50 μm) BM sections to exclude that the EGFP+/PECAM+ population overlaps with the earlier reported (Ding et al., 2012; Méndez-Ferrer et al., 2010) mesenchymal subendothelial cell populations. Our analysis revealed that the PECAM signal surrounded the entire EGFP+ cells (Figure 4E, confocal z stack showing 8 layers); hence, these elongated EGFP+ cells are of endothelial nature and clearly distinct from perivascular stromal cells. Moreover, thorough confocal analysis of BM sections revealed that mesenchymal/reticular niche markers such as PDGFRα/β or leptinR were strongly expressed in cells of the perivascular layer, which is located adjacent to these EGFP+ cells, which themselves mostly appeared to be negative for PDGFRα/β and leptinR expression, underscoring their endothelial character (Figures 4D, lower panel, and S4D). As our transgenic marker also labels, as shown above in our cell-culture experiments, stromal BM MSCs, we analyzed their spatial positioning in more detail. We found that these EGFP+/PECAM– cells are relatively rare (<0.006% of total nucleated cells, n = 4) and consistently displayed, as would be expected, a perivascular location in close proximity to the EGFP+/PECAM+ sinusoidal endothelial cell layer (Figure S4E).

Because of the close co-localization between EGFP+ sinusoidal endothelial cells and the stromal BM MSCs, we performed additional experiments to unequivocally prove the endothelial nature and to rule out stem cell characteristics for the EGFP+/PECAM+ cells. First, we cultured FACS-sorted EGFP+/PECAM+ cells in different media including specific endothelial growth medium and obtained consistently only few population doublings, as expected from primary endothelial cells. Next, we prepared primary BM bulk cultures from our transgenic mice and stained developing colonies against endothelial cell markers. We could grow EGFP+ vessel-like networks in these bulk cultures, which proved PECAM+ and endomucin+ (Figure 5 A). We also tested these cells in classic angiogenesis assays for their sprouting and tube forming capacities and found that EGFP+/PECAM+ cells from BM cultures could form typical EGFP+ networks after sorting and re-plating on Matrigel (Figure 5B). Furthermore, immunostainings of BM sections revealed the expression of endothelial nitric oxide synthase (eNOS) in a number of EGFP+ endothelial cells (Figure S5A). It is known that eNOS generates NO in blood vessels, thereby inhibiting platelet adhesion/activation, as expected from a key anti-thrombogenic agent. These cell biological and functional data implied that the BM EGFP+/PECAM+ sinusoidal cells are true endothelial cells. This would also explain their fragility, as also DiI-Ac-LDL-labeled BM endothelial cells could not be recovered in single-cell suspensions (Li et al., 2009).

ce:section.ce:section-title: CD73-EGFP Specifically Labels BM Sinusoidal Cells
ce:section.ce:para: The labeling of the sinusoidal endothelial cells was unexpected, because we could not detect EGFP expression in common endothelial cells in most other organs (as shown for uterus, liver, and fat in Figure 1). In order to unequivocally prove the true endothelial nature of the EGFP+/PECAM+ cells, we next sorted CD45– BM cells based on CD73-EGFP and PECAM expression and subjected these to single-cell multiplex gene expression analysis. Interestingly, by flow cytometry we detected EGFP+/PECAM+ as well as EGFP–/PECAM+ cells, and the EGFP+/PECAM+ cell fraction accounted for more than half of the total PECAM+ population (55.9% ± 9.8%). The non-endothelial BM MSCs that were characterized before appeared as an additional population of EGFP+ cells that lacked PECAM expression (Figure 5C). Our single-cell gene expression analysis of these three cell populations (Figure 5D) clearly underscored the endothelial cell identity of the EGFP+/PECAM+ BM population based on the expression of typical endothelial (Kdr, Emcn, Tek, Cdh5) and lack of mesenchymal genes (Cspg4, Col1a1, Prrx1). In contrast, these mesenchymal genes were, as would be expected, upregulated in the MSC population. In addition, also differences between EGFP+ and EGFP– endothelial cells were detected.

This prompted us to examine the vessels in the BM in more detail. We investigated the distribution of EGFP+ cells at different stages of aging (5, 8, and 12 weeks) in meta- and diaphysis regions of the bones. Interestingly, the columnar tubes and arches in the metaphysis (named “type H endothelium”; Kusumbe et al., 2014) were EGFP–, whereas the sinusoidal cells in the diaphysis were found to express EGFP at all stages (Figure 5E). Next, we analyzed arterial vessels passing through the cortical bone and arterioles within the BM and found that also all of these were EGFP– (Figure 5F). These results were corroborated by additional immunostainings against Sca-1 and endomucin. Confocal analysis in BM sections as well as 3D z stacks in whole mounts of the sternum revealed EGFP–/Sca-1high arteriolar cells in the parenchyma, endosteal regions, and cortical bone, whereas the sinusoidal endothelial cells were found to be EGFP+/Sca-1low (Figures 5G, 5H, and S5B). These findings are in full accordance with earlier reports on the Sca-1 expression pattern in the different BM endothelial cell types (Nombela-Arrieta et al., 2013) and support the conclusion that our CD73-EGFP mouse model labels the sinusoidal, but not other endothelial subtypes of the bone compartment.

Of relevance, the BM sinusoids have been implicated to constitute a distinct part of the hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) niche (Kunisaki and Frenette, 2014). We therefore investigated the interaction of these EGFP+ cells with hematopoietic stem/progenitor cells (HSPCs) by performing immunohistochemical stainings against c-kit on whole bone sections. We found c-kit+ hematopoietic cells mostly localized directly adjacent (60.4% ± 8.7% of c-kit+ cells (n = 5) compared to 12.3% ± 2.7% of all mononuclear cells (n = 6), p < 0.001) or in very close vicinity (mean distance of 5.9 ± 1.9 μm (n = 5) compared to 14.7 ± 1.5 μm in all mononuclear cells (n = 6), p < 0.001) to the EGFP+ sinusoids (Figure 5I). In order to assess this also for highly enriched HSCs (Kiel et al., 2005), we performed immunostainings in whole mounts of the sternum, as described earlier (Kunisaki et al., 2013). Some lineage–/CD48–/CD150+ HSCs were found in direct vicinity to EGFP+ sinusoidal structures (Figure S5C), but their overall co-localization with sinusoids appeared to be rather random (34.6% were located within 10 μm distance from EGFP+ sinusoids, mean distance of 14.3 μm; n = 26 cells from 4 mice) compared to the c-kit+ hematopoietic cells.

ce:section.ce:section-title: CD73-EGFP+ Sinusoidal Cells Are a Distinct Endothelial Subtype in the Bone Compartment
ce:section.ce:para: Because of the lack of specific markers, sinusoidal endothelial cells could so far not be characterized in detail at the molecular level. We therefore sorted CD73-EGFP+/PECAM+/CD45– sinusoidal cells and corresponding controls (see Figure 5C) and examined their cellular and molecular profile by RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) transcriptome analyses. Computational analysis demonstrated that biological triplicates clustered together, while the three cell populations clearly separated (Figure 6 A). The consistency of the gene expression data was further substantiated by the correlation of PECAM and CD73 expression levels to the sorting parameters in the respective isolated cell populations (Figure 6B). To further substantiate the molecular characteristics of the three cell populations, we looked for expression of typical endothelial and mesenchymal genes. As expected, we found several endothelial genes such as endomucin (Emcm), VE-cadherin (Cdh5), CD34, flk-1 (Kdr), Tie2 (Tek), and Tie1 to be highly expressed in both PECAM+ populations when compared to PECAM– cells, underscoring that both populations are endothelial cells (see boxplots of selected set of genes in Figure 6C and S6A). On the other hand, we detected higher expression levels of mesenchymal markers such as Pdgfra/b, leptinR (LepR), collagenase 1a1/2 (Col1a1/2), or Cxcl12 (Figures 6D and S6B) in the EGFP+/PECAM– cells, in line with their MSC character. Importantly, gene expression analysis also revealed clear differences between EGFP+/PECAM+ sinusoidal and EGFP–/PECAM+ arteriolar endothelial cells, which may explain their suggested different functions within the HSC niche. It is noteworthy that Vcam1, known to be involved in HSC retention and mobilization (Dutta et al., 2015), is significantly higher expressed in the sinusoidal, than arteliolar endothelial fraction (Figure 6E). Also, E-selectin (Sele), which was reported to be a crucial component of the vascular niche (Winkler et al., 2012), is higher expressed in EGFP+ compared to EGFP– endothelial cells (Figure 6E). This was further supported by our single-cell multiplex gene expression analysis data (see Figure 5D), as sinusoidal endothelial genes found to be upregulated in our RNA-seq data (CD36, Sele, Cxcl9, Vcam1) were observed to be also more consistently expressed in EGFP+ sinusoidal than EGFP– arteriolar endothelial cells. These findings were corroborated by immunohistochemical stainings demonstrating stronger expression of E-selectin (Figure 6F) and Vcam1 (Figure 6G) also at the protein level, in the EGFP+ sinusoidal endothelium compared to the EGFP– arterial vessels and arterioles. Interestingly, also the endothelial networks in BM bulk cultures recapitulated the expression pattern of these sinusoidal markers, again underscoring their sinusoidal character (Figure S5D). These experimental data clearly prove that bona fide sinusoidal endothelial cells within the BM are EGFP+/PECAM+ and that these cells display molecular differences in respect to the arteriolar endothelial cell population in the BM.

For a more detailed molecular characterization of the respective three cell populations, we next performed additional gene set enrichment analysis (GSEA) of the PECAM+ versus PECAM– cell fractions. This revealed a strong congruence with gene signatures of PECAM+ endothelial-like cells and PECAM– stromal stem cells from adipose tissue that were described before (Boquest et al., 2005), in line with our cellular characterization (Figure S6C, left panel). Further GSEA comparing the sinusoidal EGFP+/PECAM+ and arteriolar EGFP–/PECAM+ endothelial cell populations (Figure S6C, right panel) using the same published consensus gene signatures showed that the sinusoidal cells expressed some genes of the proposed stromal stem cell signature (BOQUEST_STEM_CELL_UP), though at a low level, while prominent expression of endothelial genes proved their endothelial character (Figure 7 , left panel). Assessment of gene signature activity confirmed a significant upregulation of this potential stromal stem cell gene signature in the EGFP+ sinusoidal cells (p < 0.005), while the expression level of the endothelial cell signature was similar (p = 0.14) to the EGFP– arteriolar cells (Figure 7, right panels). Although it is not clear whether the low-level expression of potential stromal stem cell genes in EGFP+ sinusoidal cells is related to a mesenchymal ancestry or rather to their functional status, these findings provide clear evidence for endothelial heterogeneity within the BM compartment.

In this study, we used a newly generated CD73-EGFP reporter mouse model for the visualization and molecular characterization of multipotent stromal cells and distinct BM sinusoidal endothelial cells in vivo.

Herein we demonstrate that the CD73-EGFP construct enables the direct isolation of a cell population containing multipotent stromal cells from the intact bone compartment with the ability of clonal expansion and trilineage differentiation. In order to unequivocally prove that these CD45–/PECAM–/EGFP+ cells are true mesenchymal stem cells, further in vivo experiments are required demonstrating their sustained self-renewal capacity and multipotency through lineage tracing and/or transplantation studies.

In a recent study using Gli1 as a marker to visualize and purify MSCs, the authors did not find significant levels of CD73 expression on their isolated cells (Kramann et al., 2015). Because these cells could, as our CD73-EGFP+ cells, be differentiated into the typical mesenchymal lineages, these findings point to the existence of different subtypes of MSCs in vivo. Such an heterogeneity is further supported by other mouse models, in which BM MSCs were reported to be labeled by nestin (Méndez-Ferrer et al., 2010) or leptin receptor (LepR) (Zhou et al., 2014). While nestin was present in the Gli1+ progenitor cells, it was only expressed at low levels in the LepR+ cells. Also in our CD73-EGFP+ BM MSCs, nestin expression levels were found to be very low, whereas LepR was abundantly expressed. The characterization of nestin+ or LepR+ cells was only assessed in the BM; therefore, their distribution and identity in other organs is yet not known. Previous studies have proposed a close relationship of MSCs to pericytes based on their distribution throughout the post-natal organism (da Silva Meirelles et al., 2006). Moreover, a perivascular origin of these cells was suggested based on immunohistochemical stainings against several mesenchymal markers such as CD146 and PDGFRβ (Crisan et al., 2008). However, there is still a lack of information regarding the precise anatomical location of MSCs in the respective organs. Our imaging data revealed that MSCs are located in vicinity to or directly lining PECAM+ vessels in various tissues and express CD146 as well as Sca-1, typical markers for murine MSCs. In addition, EGFP+ mesenchymal progenitors could be detected in the proliferative zone of embryonic and adult bones, where they induce perichondral and endochondral ossification. The ability of MSCs for bone formation in vivo is well known and was also shown for nestin+ and LepR+ cells in the bone compartment (Méndez-Ferrer et al., 2010; Zhou et al., 2014). Fate-mapping experiments using LepR-Cre revealed contribution to bone cells only in adult mice and little or no contribution to cartilage. CD73-EGFP+ cells might label an earlier class of osteochondral progenitors from which later subpopulations such as LepR+ cells could originate. It would be therefore interesting to generate an inducible CD73-Cre mouse model for carrying out lineage tracing and fate-mapping experiments to explore the developmental hierarchy, heterogeneity, and biological diversity of prospective MSC populations under different conditions.

Mesenchymal progenitors are not only suggested to play a critical role in bone development, but also for the formation of the HSC niche in the BM (Sacchetti et al., 2007) by recruiting vasculature into the center of the developing bone graft (Chan et al., 2009). However, the origin and nature of these vessels is not clear, as endothelial cells are thought to be highly heterogeneous. In the BM, at least two major types of endothelium have been identified, the sinusoidal and the arteriolar population (Itkin et al., 2016; Kunisaki and Frenette, 2014). In addition, Kusumbe et al. recently discovered another specific type of endothelial cells in the metaphysis named type H endothelium, which is only present in young mice and involved in bone vessel growth (Kusumbe et al., 2014). In the BM, our CD73-EGFP reporter specifically labels a distinct sinusoidal endothelial cell fraction, which has been implicated to be a key component of the HSC niche (Winkler et al., 2012). This is of particular interest, because BM sinusoids and arterioles might provide different molecular cues and functions for the maintenance of HSCs (Kunisaki and Frenette, 2014), although to date the sinusoidal endothelial cells could hardly be purified or enriched due to the lack of highly specific genetic models or marker molecules. In fact, almost all current approaches to distinguish between arterial and sinusoidal ECs are indirect methods requiring pretreatment of the animals by intravital labeling. In addition, intravital dyes such as Dil-Ac-LDL (Li et al., 2009) or antibodies such as Sca-1 (Nombela-Arrieta et al., 2013) often cause inhomogeneous and patchy labeling, whereas CD73-EGFP enables identification, imaging, and isolation of this distinct endothelial subtype.

Nolan et al. recently characterized molecular signatures of various tissue-specific microvascular endothelial cell populations but did not discriminate between the different BM endothelial compartments (Nolan et al., 2013). We took advantage of our CD73-EGFP mouse model to isolate EGFP+ and EGFP– endothelial cell populations from the BM and provide molecular, cell biological, and functional evidence that the CD45–/PECAM+/EGFP+ cells are indeed the sinusoidal endothelial cells. Interestingly, gene expression profiling using RNA-seq and subsequent gene set enrichment analysis revealed that these cells in comparison to CD45–/PECAM+/EGFP– arteriolar endothelium display differences in the expression pattern of several endothelial genes and in addition some traits of a previously published stromal stem cell gene signature. Its significance is not clear, and future studies need to address whether this as well as CD73 expression is related to a mesenchymal ancestry of the cells or rather to their functional status. The above-mentioned inducible CD73-Cre mouse model could be helpful to provide insight into the developmental origin of these different cell types and whether CD73 plays a role in mesenchymal tissue and sinusoidal vessel formation, homeostasis, and/or regeneration. In any case, our data clearly show the distinct molecular signature of the sinusoidal endothelium in respect to other endothelial subtypes in the bone compartment and most likely also in other organs and this underscores the concept of endothelial heterogeneity within the same compartment. The molecular characterization of the endothelial subtypes in the BM also demonstrates different expression levels of genes that are involved in regulation of hematopoiesis. We found, e.g., higher expression of E-selectin and Vcam-1 in sinusoidal cells compared to arteriolar endothelium, both adhesion molecules that are directly involved in HSC signaling (Dutta et al., 2015; Winkler et al., 2012). The list of all differentially expressed genes provides insight into the regulatory network of the different endothelial HSC niche compartments in the BM. Finding more factors that orchestrate the HSC niche will help to understand the tightly controlled balance of HSC proliferation and quiescence, mobilization, and dormancy, and herein we provide a helpful and detailed gene expression library as a resource for this purpose. Future efforts should also be directed toward intravital microscopy in order to directly visualize the sinusoidal cells and track them and interacting cells during immunological challenges such as mobilization, inflammation, and infection.

The surprisingly strong expression of CD73 on sinusoidal cells in contrast to BM arterioles and endothelium in other organs indicates a potential role of CD73 as a regulating factor in the HSC niche. Besides its direct function as adhesion molecule, this membrane-bound enzyme catalyzes the extracellular conversion of adenosine monophosphate to adenosine. This pathway is particularly interesting in light of recent evidence for a functional role of adenosine signaling in HSC emergence in zebrafish (Jing et al., 2015). Moreover, adenosine receptor signaling was suggested to enhance cycling of hematopoietic progenitor cells (Pospísil et al., 2001), in line with the proposed impact of the sinusoids on HSC proliferation. This fits with our data, which reveal close co-localization of c-kit+ hematopoietic progenitor cells with CD73-EGFP+ sinusoids, whereas the spatial distribution pattern is less stringent for the preferentially quiescent CD150+ HSCs. Further studies taking for instance advantage of CD73 KO models will be helpful to explore a possible functional role of CD73 in the HSC niche.

Taken together, we provide a genetic model enabling the identification and imaging of at least a proportion of multipotent stromal cells in vivo. In addition, our genetic model labels sinusoidal cells within the BM endothelial compartment allowing cellular and molecular characterization of this suggested component of the HSC niche.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Contact for Reagent and Resource Sharing
ce:section.ce:para: Further information and requests for resources and reagents should be directed to and will be fulfilled by the Lead Contact, Martin Breitbach (mbreitba@uni-bonn.de).

All mouse experiments complied with procedures approved by the regional and local Animal Care Committees. Male and female mice of various ages (embryonic stage E14 up to 6 months) were used throughout this study. Mice used for experiments were not involved in previous procedures and were drug or test naive.

The CD73-BAC-EGFP mouse line was generated on a mixed background (G4 ES cells aggregated with diploid morula stage CD1 embryos) and backcrossed by heterozygous breeding with female C57BL/6J wild-type mice (up to 11th generation). Mice were kept in a SPF breeding area under specified pathogen free conditions. Cages, bedding, food and water were autoclaved. Animals were maintained on the same 12 h light/dark cycle and monitored daily by caretakers and researchers. Health monitoring happens by using Sentinels to FELASA guidelines. Quarterly or half-yearly health monitoring did not reveal any infections during the past 6 years.

MSCs from BM, epiphyses, crushed bones, bone fragments, and adipose tissue were cultured in MEM alpha supplemented with 15% FBS, 50 U/ml Penicillin, 50 μg/ml Streptomycin (all from Invitrogen), and 5 ng/ml basic FGF (Peprotech, Hamburg, Germany) in a hypoxia incubator at 37°C and 2% oxygen on adherent tissue culture plates (Invitrogen). The medium was replaced with fresh medium twice a week. Cells were trypsinized with 0.05% trypsin-EDTA (Invitrogen) when reaching 80% confluence, and expanded for further analysis or stored in liquid nitrogen. FACS sorted EGFP+/PECAM+ cells were cultured in different media including MEM alpha (see above), MesenCult medium (StemCell Technologies, Cologne, Germany), or specific endothelial growth medium (Provitro, Berlin, Germany). G4 ES cells were cultured in Knockout DMEM supplemented with 15% fetal bovine serum (FBS), 2 mM L-glutamine, 0.1 mM MEM, 50 U/ml Penicillin, 50 μg/ml Streptomycin, 0.1 mM 2-Mercaptoethanol, 165 μg/ml G418 (all from Invitrogen), and 1000 U/ml LIF (Chemicon, Hampshire, England).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Generation of transgenic CD73-EGFP BAC mice
Selection of CD73 as a marker molecule
ce:section.ce:para: Our literature search identified CD73 as a strong candidate marker molecule for the direct identification of multipotent stromal cells (MSCs). CD73 is a membrane-bound ecto-5′-nucleotidase catalyzing the dephosphorylation of AMP to adenosine. It is a well-established marker for cultured MSCs and known to display only moderate distribution in other mesodermal cell types (Resta et al., 1993). CD73 is also present on some cells of the hematopoietic lineage (Zimmermann, 1992), but these cells can be easily discriminated from MSCs by their morphology and expression of specific blood cell markers such as CD45. In addition, CD73 has been reported to be expressed in epithelial cells of several organs such as kidney and lung (Resta et al., 1993), but this was not relevant for our purpose, as we focused on the identification of MSCs in non-epithelial organs such as bone or fat.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Generation of the CD73-EGFP BAC vector
ce:section.ce:para: A BAC clone covering the complete promoter region of the CD73 gene including 100 kb upstream and 35 kb downstream regulatory elements (RP24-316M18) was obtained from the Children`s Hospital Oakland Research Institute (CHORI). Then, an EGFP-pA cDNA was inserted at the initiation codon into the first exon of the CD73 gene within the BACs. Therefore, homologous arms were generated by PCR using the pEGFP-1 vector as template. For this end the following primers were applied: fw: 5` TGC TCA CTG GGC TCA GGG CCA GTC CAC CCG CTC AAC GCG CTC TAG CCA GCC TGG CCA CAA CCA TGG TGAG 3`; rev: 5` CCA GCC TTT CTC TCT CTG GGT CTG GGA CTC CTA CCC CGG GAA CTT TCT CCT TAC CCC GCG TTT ATG AAC AAA CGAC 3`. Next, SW105 E. Coli cells containing the BACs were electroporated with the targeting cassette and clones with successful recombination were selected with kanamycin and chloramphenicol. Homologous recombination was verified by PCR with primers spanning the homology region. Functionality of the construct was validated in established MSC cultures (see also Figure S1). Then, the CD73-EGFP BAC was used for electroporation in G4 embryonic stem (ES) cells (George et al., 2007).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Generation of transgenic ES cell clones
ce:section.ce:para: To generate transgenic CD73-EGFP BAC ES cell clones 3 × 106 G4 ES cells were mixed with 5 μg of the CD73-EGFP BAC in PBS, electroporated with one pulse at 240 V and 500 μF (Bio-Rad Gene Pulser Xcell, Munich, Germany) and plated on 10 cm cell culture dishes with feeder cells. After selection by G418 (165 μg/ml) (Neomycin, Invitrogen, Karlsruhe, Germany), resistant colonies were picked and propagated for differentiation.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Differentiation of transgenic ES cell clones
ce:section.ce:para: ES cell differentiation was performed using embryoid bodies (EB) formation via hanging drop method. For differentiation cells were cultivated in Iscovés DMEM high-glucose medium (Invitrogen) supplemented with 20% FBS plus additives in the absence of LIF. After 5 days of differentiation transgenic EBs were plated on coverslips coated with 0.1% gelatine solution (Sigma-Aldrich, Steinheim, Germany). Then, EGFP expression could be evaluated on a daily basis and was consistently seen in different ES cell clones by day 5 to 6 of differentiation, coinciding with the formation of mesodermal structures, as expected for MSC development.

For generation of transgenic mice CD73-EGFP (BAC) G4 ES cell clones were screened for normal 40 chromosome karyotype. Then, the selected ES cells were aggregated with diploid morula stage CD1 embryos (Charles River Laboratories, Wilmington, MA, USA) as described previously (Nagy et al., 1990). Chimeric mice could be identified by their coat color and were bred with C57BL/6J mice (The Jackson Laboratory, Bar Harbor, ME, USA, JAX#006494) to examine germline transmission. Offspring was tested for transgene expression by PCR of the tail tips with the following primer pair: fw: 5` ACT CCG CAG TTT AGT AGA GG 3`, rev: 5` GTC TTG TAG TTG CCG TCG TC 3`. Specificity of the construct was analyzed in tissue sections (see also Figure S2).

For isolation of BM MSCs femurs and tibiae were isolated from 2- to 3-month-old mice and the adherent soft tissue was removed thoroughly. The epiphyses were cut by scissors and cultured in MEM alpha supplemented with 15% FBS, 50 U/ml Penicillin, 50 μg/ml Streptomycin (all from Invitrogen), and 5 ng/ml basic FGF (Peprotech, Hamburg, Germany) in a hypoxia incubator at 2% oxygen on adherent tissue culture plates (Invitrogen). BM cells were flushed with a 27-G needle from femurs and tibiae and suspended with PBS/2% FBS. Alternatively, complete long bones were crushed by mortar and pestle and BM cells were rinsed with PBS/2% FBS. For isolation of cells from bone fragments the crushed bones were rinsed and further minced by scissors and digested with 0.1% collagenase 1 (Worthington, Lakewood, NJ) for 45 min at 37°C. Bone fragments were washed gently and cell suspension filtered through a 100 μm nylon mesh. Mouse adipose tissues were treated similarly, minced by scissors, digested with collagenase, and filtered. All cells were cultured in medium as described above. The medium was replaced with fresh medium twice a week. Cells were trypsinized with 0.05% trypsin-EDTA (Invitrogen) when reaching 80% confluence, and expanded for further analysis or stored in liquid nitrogen.

ce:section.ce:section-title: In vitro differentiation of MSC populations
ce:section.ce:para: In vitro differentiation of cultured MSCs was performed as described earlier with minor modifications (Breitbach et al., 2007). For osteogenic differentiation, cells were seeded at 3x104 cells/well in a 24-well plate and differentiated for 28 days in induction medium (0.1 μM dexamethasone, 500 μM ascorbic acid, and 10 mM β-glycerol phosphate in MEM alpha/10% FCS), fixed in 4% formalin and stained with 2% Alizarin Red solution. For adipogenic differentiation, cells were seeded at 3x104 cells/well in a 24-well plate and differentiated for 28 days in induction medium (0.25 μM dexamethasone, 450 μM isobutylmethylxanthine, 1.4 μM hydrocortisone, 200 μM indomethacine, and 1.15 μM insulin in MEM alpha/10% FCS), fixed in 4% formalin and stained with 0.5% Oil Red O solution. For chondrogenic differentiation, cells were seeded at 2x105 cells/well in a U-bottom 96-well plate and differentiated for 28 days in induction medium (0.1 μM dexamethasone, 500 μM ascorbic acid, 35 mM proline and 1 mM sodium pyruvate in MEM alpha/ITS-Supplement), fixed in 4% formalin and stained with 1% Alcian Blue solution. All chemicals were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich. For all differentiations, cells grown in MEM alpha/15% FCS for 28 days served as control. Medium was changed twice a week.

Trypsinized cultured cells or primary cells were stained with APC-labeled antibodies against CD3 (17A2), CD4 (RM4-5), CD8 (53-6.7), CD11b (M1/70), CD11c (HL3), CD44 (IM7), CD45 (30F11), CD73 (TY/23), CD146 (ME-9F1), Sca-1 (E13-161.7) (1:200, all from BD PharMingen, Franklin Lakes, NJ), PerCP-labeled antibody against B220 (RA3-6B2, BD PharMingen), or Alexa 647-labeled antibody against Sca-1 (1:200, D7, Biolegend, San Diego, CA) for 20 min at 4°C. After washing the expression of surface markers was measured using flow cytometry (CyFlow Space, Partec, Münster, Germany). Data were analyzed with FlowJo (Tree Star, Ashland, OR). Sorting experiments were performed using a FACSAria Cell Sorter (BD Bioscience). Single cells were seeded by an automated cell deposition unit (ACDU) into 96-well plates providing single cells in > 99% of the wells, and no wells with more than one cell. Cells for RNA sequencing and single cell Fluidigm analysis were prepared by crushing of long bones and pelves as described above. Red blood cells were removed by incubation with NH4Cl hemolytic buffer for 2 min. Whole BM cells were depleted for CD45+ blood cells by magnetic beads according to the manufacturer’s instructions (mouse CD45 MicroBeads, Miltenyi Biotec, Bergisch Gladbach, Germany). Cells were stained with anti-CD45-PE (30F11), anti-Ter119-PerCPCy5.5 (TER-119), and anti-PECAM-APC (MEC13.3) (BD PharMingen). 7AAD (BD PharMingen) was added prior to measurement for exclusion of dead cells. Gates were placed based on FMOs and drawn tightly to prevent contamination of sorted populations.

To evaluate the differentiation potential of EGFP+ BM cells whole BM was plated as described above at a density of 25,000 cells/cm2, and cultured for 14 days. Developing colonies (colony forming units - fibroblast, CFU-Fs) were checked for EGFP expression and CFU-Fs that almost exclusively consisted of EGFP+ cells were marked. Medium was switched to induction medium to initiate differentiation into the osteogenic or adipogenic lineage. After 25 days the marked colonies were screened for bone formation or adipocytes, respectively.

Freshly isolated cells from bone fragments were stained with anti-CD45-APC and CD45-/EGFP+ cells were sorted by flow cytometry. Sorted cells were plated at a density of 100-200 cells/cm2, and cultured for 14 days as described above. For quantification of CFU-Fs, cells were fixed in 4% formalin and stained with 0.5% crystal violet solution in methanol (Sigma-Aldrich). Colonies with more than 50 cells were counted.

Whole BM cells or cells from bone fragments were isolated from CD73-EGFP mice as described above and stained with anti-CD45-PE and anti-PECAM-APC antibody. Single CD45-/EGFP+/PECAM- cells were sorted into MEM alpha in 96-well plates as described above. The medium was replaced with fresh medium twice a week. Cells were trypsinized with 0.05% trypsin-EDTA (Invitrogen) when reaching 80% confluence and expanded for differentiation assays.

FACS sorted EGFP+/PECAM+ cells were plated in a 10 cm dish and cultured in MesenCult medium (StemCell Technologies, Cologne, Germany) for 21 days. Immunostainings in cell culture dishes were performed as described for tissue sections. For re-plating trypsinized cells were stained with anti-CD45-PE and anti-PECAM-APC antibody, and 10,000 CD45-/EGFP+/PECAM+ cells per well were sorted on matrigel (BD Bioscience) in a 96-well plate. Then, cells were incubated for 8-12 hours and tube formation was analyzed by microscopy.

Femoral or tibial bones, liver, spleen, kidney, fat, and uterus were fixed in 4% formalin overnight, incubated in 10% or 20% sucrose for cryopreservation. Soft tissues were embedded in OCT compound (Tissue-Tek; Sakura Finetek, Torrance, CA) and cryosectioned (10 μm) using a cryostat (Leica CM3050S; Leica Microsystems, Wetzlar, Germany). Bones were embedded in SCEM (Section-Lab Co. Ltd., Japan) and sectioned (5 μm) using a cryostat according to the Kawamoto method (Kawamoto, 2003). Sections were permeabilized in PBS containing 0.1% Tween 20, and blocked in PBS with 5% donkey serum for 20 min. Then, sections were stained with mouse anti-osteopontin (DSHB, Iowa, IA), rat anti-PECAM (MEC13.3), rat anti-Sca1 (E13-161.7), rat anti-CD73 (TY/23), rat anti-Vcam1 (MVCAM.A), mouse anti eNos (NOS Type III), rat anti-CD62E (10E9.6) (BD PharMingen), goat anti-ckit, goat anti-leptinR-biotin, goat anti-endomucin (R&D systems, Minneapolis, MN), rat anti-CD45 (IBL-5/25) (Merck, Darmstadt, Deutschland), rat anti-CD146 (ME-9F1) (Biolegend), rat anti-endomucin (V.7C7) (Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Dallas, Texas), rat anti-CD140a/PDGFRa (APA5), rat anti-CD140b/PDGFRb (APB5) (eBioscience, San Diego, CA), rabbit anti-LYVE1 (Relia Tech, Wolfenbüttel, Germany), or rabbit anti-Nestin (Abcam, Cambridge, UK). Cy3- or Cy5-conjugated secondary donkey antibodies (all from Jackson ImmunoResearch, West Grove, PA, 1:400) were used for visualization, and nuclei were stained with Hoechst 33342 (Sigma-Aldrich). Sternal bone was perfusion fixed and post fixed 30 min in 4% formalin, incubated in 10% or 20% sucrose, and cut into 2-3 fragments and bisected for the BM cavity to be exposed. Whole mount tissue was permeabilized/blocked in PBS containing 20% donkey serum and 0.5% Tween 20, and stained with biotin-anti-lineage (TER-119, RB6-8C5, RA3-6B2, M1/70, 145-2C11), biotin-anti-CD48 (HM48-1) (Biolegend) and PE-anti-CD150 (TC15-12F12.2, BD Bioscience) for 1-3 days. The tissue was stained with secondary antibody in PBS with Hoechst 33342 for 6 hr. Images were acquired using an inverted fluorescence microscope (Axiovert 200) equipped with a slider module (ApoTome; Carl Zeiss MicroImaging, Oberkochen, Deutschland) and a confocal microscope (ECLIPSE Ti; Nikon, Japan). Composite pictures of whole tissues (2A, 2B, S2A, S2B) were imaged by a 25 × oil objective and stitched using AxioVision MosaiX software (Zeiss).

Cells were pelleted, shock-frozen in liquid nitrogen and homogenized in TRIzol (Invitrogen). RNA was isolated following the manufacturer’s protocol and traces of DNA were removed by DNase treatment (QIAGEN, Hilden, Germany). Integrity of RNA extracts was assessed on a 1% MOPS gel. First strand complementary DNA (cDNA) was synthesized using the SuperScript VILO cDNA Synthese Kit (Invitrogen). Real-time PCR was performed on a Corbett Rotor-Gene 6000 real time PCR cycler (QIAGEN) using TaqMan gene expression master mix and assays for CD73 and 18S rRNA (Applied Biosystems, Darmstadt, Germany).

For multiplex gene expression analysis single cells were sorted directly into RT/pre-amplification mix (Invitrogen). Multiplex quantitative PCR analysis (BioMark 192.24 Dynamic Array platform; Fluidigm) using TaqMan Gene Expression Assays (Applied Biosystems) was performed as previously described (Luis et al., 2016). TaqMan assays used for the analysis are shown in Table S1. Analysis of single cell expression data was performed using the R/Bioconductor computing platform.

Samples for RNA sequencing were prepared using the SMARTer Ultra Low RNA kit for Illumina Sequencing (Clontech, Mountain View, CA) according to manufacturer’s instructions as previously described (Ramsköld et al., 2012). Briefly, 100 cells were sorted directly into lysis buffer supplemented with RNase Inhibitor (Clontech). cDNA library was prepared according to manufacturer instructions with 15 cycles of amplification. Amplified cDNA libraries validated with a distinct peak spanning 400 bp to 9000 bp in size as measured by High Sensitivity DNA kit (Agilent, Santa Clara, CA) on Agilent 2100 Bioanalyzer were further processed for RNA sequencing. A Nextera kit (Illumina, San Diego, CA) was used for Tn5-mediated fragmentation and indexing of individual samples according to manufacturer’s instructions. The size of the amplified fragments was confirmed by Agilent High Sensitivity DNA Kit. 6-8 samples with different indexes were pooled per lane and sequenced on HiSeq 2000 (Illumina) generating single–end, 50 bp reads.

All experiments were performed at least three times and representative images were chosen for publication. Where appropriate, the number of experiments is given (individual mice or biological replicates if not stated otherwise). All values are represented as mean ± SD. Statistical significance of experimental results was evaluated with GraphPad Prism4 software using the parametric unpaired two-tailed Student’s t test. P values less than 0.05 were considered significant and presented as ∗ when p < 0.05; ∗∗ when p < 0.01; ∗∗∗ when p < 0.001. No significance was presented as ns.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Quantification of hematopoietic stem/progenitor cell distribution
ce:section.ce:para: After immunostaining of c-kit+ hematopoietic cells or lineage-/CD48-/CD150+ HSCs confocal images were taken and the distance of individual cells (1837 c-kit+ cells from 5 mice; 26 HSCs from 4 mice) to EGFP+ sinusoidal structures was measured using NIS-Elements Confocal Software (Nikon). As a control, distance of random mononuclear cells (MNC) was determined (more than 5000 cells from 6 mice).
The CD73 expression was normalized using 18S rRNA as an internal control. Results are expressed in fold change values compared with mean MSC expression levels (ΔΔCt method).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Single cell multiplex gene expression analysis
ce:section.ce:para: All Ct values obtained from the BioMark System were analyzed by the ΔCt method, using the house-keeping gene B2m as endogenous control for normalization in individual cells and by subtracting the values from the assumed detection limit of 28. Raw Ct values beyond detection level limit were set to zero. Cells with low or absent endogenous control gene expression levels were removed from analysis and only cells were included with corresponding expression of the respective FACS sorting parameters (CD45, EGFP, PECAM; 55% of total samples).

FASTQ raw sequencing read files were analyzed using the open source Bioconductor platform embedded in the R-programing environment. Reads were mapped to the mouse reference genome (Mm10) using the Rsubread aligner and subsequently assigned to NCBI reference genes using the ‘featureCounts’ read summarization function (Liao et al., 2013). After conversion into a ‘DGEList’-object using the ‘edgeR’-package we performed normalization with the ‘voom’ method from the ‘limma’-package for subsequent linear modeling approaches (Law et al., 2014; Robinson et al., 2010). Sample relationships were visualized by computing a distance matrix (euclidean distance) from the voom-normalized gene expression data with a gene expression variance-cutoff of 0.5 and subsequent hierarchical clustering analysis using DIANA divisive clustering. Visualization was done with a phylogenetic tree plot from the ape-package using the edge lengths of the phylogeny to draw the length of the branches. Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) was done using the preranked gene list method implemented in the java-based GSEA program and the C2 curated molecular signature database both provided by the BROAD institute (https://www.broadinstitute.org/gsea/index.jsp). The gene expression dataset was filtered to remove genes with low-level expression for noise reduction (after normalization voom-normalized log2 expression value of 4 was used as cutoff based on a prior density plot analysis).

Because of the low biological replicate number a moderated eBayes t test statistic (limma-package) was used to generate a gene-wise rank metric as input for the GSEA preranked gene list algorithm. Using either log2-fold changes or t test values as ranked metric generated similar GSEA results using the preranked gene list mode. Consensus gene signatures (Stromal stem cell signature, endothelial cell-like signature) for heatmap cluster analysis were built from GSEA leading edge analysis of the top-ranking gene sets retrieved from the comparison between EGFP+/PECAM- versus EGFP+/PECAM+ and EGFP-/PECAM+ cell populations. Voom-normalized gene expression data was mean centered and row-wise z-score transformed for heatmap visualization. The sample order was fixed, but the genes were hierarchically clustered. Assessment of gene signature activity in the three FACS-sorted cell populations was done by calculating the mean z-score of the three replicates in a gene-wise manner. Gene-wise mean z-scores of the signatures were then visualized by a boxplot grouped by the three cell populations. Significance of difference was determined by an unpaired two-sided and pairwise t test with Bonferroni correction for multiple testing. GSEA results were visualized by vulcano plots representing the normalized enrichment scores (NES) on the x-axes and the FDR-adjusted (False-discovery-rate) p values (-log10) on the y-axes. Selected top ranking gene sets were highlighted by red or blue circles depending on their enrichment. Full GSEA results are provided as Tables S2, S3, S4, S5, S6, and S7.
The accession number for the raw sequencing data reported in this paper is European Nucleotide Archive (ENA): PRJEB23422 (ERP105176) (https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ena/data/view/PRJEB23422).
